isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 9800 - MAJOR STRUCTURAL REPAIR: 9600 - FASTENERS AND SEALERS - FASTENERS

step1.para: Replace old rivets with the next larger size (such as 3/16" old would go to 1/4" new).
Use aluminum rivets to replace aluminum rivets. Use steel to replace steel. if steel rivets are used, they must be coated to prevent corrosion in contact with the aluminum.
Replacement fasteners should be of the same type as the ones removed. The solid squeeze rivets may be replaced by lockbolts and collars of the proper grip length,if desired.

if you cannot get at both sides, use Monobolts or erry G's. Use Cherry G's if the surface is curved, or if you need greater clamp-up power to pull several thicknesses of material together. Use Monobolts to fasten two flat parts together.

There are some places where spot welds are used in the assembly of this cab. Use plug welds to reassemble if a weld is necessary. in some places, such as attaching the tunnel to the tunnel rails, 1/4" Lockbolts may be used instead of welds. Plug welding, because of its high heat, may distort large panels. Lockbolts do not cause this problem.

At the forward end of the tunnel, there are places where the original fasteners should be replaced with 5/16" Magnagrips. If your equipment cannot pull 5/16" Magnagrips, replace the fasteners with 5/16", grade #8, hex head, coated bolts.

In the case of older cabs with serial numbers below 16529, you should replace the original aluminum rivets in the area of the gusset (which is located at the left front corner of the tunnel) with coated steel rivets or bolts following the rules that have been stated above. Figure 8 shows this area in detail. This is an area of great stress and it is very important to use the correct fasteners.
